content: The Act may be cited as the "NASA Innovation Fund and Sponsorship Act of 2007". It includes a section on the NASA Innovation Fund. The "NASA Innovation Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by charitable donations or program proceeds. The Fund can be used for advertising purposes, limited to 10% of the transferred amounts per fiscal year, not exceeding $1,000,000. The NASA Innovation Fund allows for the use of transferred amounts for advertising, administration expenses, and prize money under specific limitations. The Secretary of the Treasury is responsible for investing any remaining funds. The NASA Innovation Fund allows for the use of transferred amounts for prize money under specific limitations. The Secretary of the Treasury is responsible for investing any remaining funds in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. The NASA Innovation Fund allows for the acquisition and sale of obligations, with interest and proceeds credited to the Fund. NASA Innovation Fund allows for the acquisition and sale of obligations, with interest and proceeds credited to the Fund. SEC. 3. NASA INNOVATION FUND SPONSORSHIP ADVISORY COMMITTEE. The NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee is established within NASA to advise on program implementation. The committee consists of 5 US citizens with expertise in education and promotional activities, appointed by the Administrator. A Chair and Vice Chair will also be appointed. The NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee consists of 5 US citizens with expertise in education and promotional activities. The Administrator appoints individuals from academia, the nonprofit sector, and the private sector to serve on the committee. Each member serves a three-year term with staggered initial terms for continuity. Vacancies are filled if a member departs before their term expires. The Advisory Committee members serve staggered three-year terms with no compensation for their services. Vacancies are filled if a member leaves before their term ends, and members cannot serve for more than 6 years. The Advisory Committee members serve staggered three-year terms with no compensation. Committee members may not serve for more than 6 years. Meetings must be held at least 4 times a year, with NASA officials present to provide guidance. Members are reimbursed for travel expenses. SEC. 4. INNOVATION FUND SPONSORSHIP PROGRAM. The Administrator is authorized to create an Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program allowing individuals to use the Partnership Logo in exchange for a monetary contribution. A person approved for the program is known as a "sponsor". The logo will include the words "NASA Innovation Fund Partner" as recommended by the Advisory Committee. The Administrator will select a logo for the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program based on the Advisory Committee's recommendations. To apply as a sponsor, a person must submit an application with the amount to be contributed and a description of the promotional program. The Advisory Committee reviews proposals for the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program and makes recommendations to the Administrator. Each application must include the amount to be contributed and a detailed description of the promotional program using the Partnership Logo, focusing on promoting education in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program aims to promote education in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics by directing audiences to relevant information, promoting educational programs in STEM fields, and encouraging study and employment opportunities in these disciplines. Approved applicants must enter into a sponsorship agreement with the Administrator, requiring a specified contribution and allowing the use of the Partnership Logo in their promotional programs. The agreement with the Administrator for the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program requires a specified contribution and allows the use of the Partnership Logo in promotional programs. Restrictions include no logos on spacecraft, no astronaut endorsements, and no agency-wide endorsements by NASA. The Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program agreement prohibits logos on spacecraft, astronaut endorsements, agency-wide endorsements by NASA, in-kind contributions, contributions below a minimum amount set by the Administrator, and any other features deemed inappropriate. NASA also protects proprietary information. The Administrator establishes procedures to protect proprietary information submitted under the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program. Congress encourages NASA to participate in activities authorized in the National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958 and provide assistance to sponsors for promotional programs. Enforcement measures are also outlined. NASA is encouraged to carry out authorized activities and provide assistance to sponsors for promotional programs. Unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo may result in civil action and penalties. The Administrator may take civil action for unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo, with penalties of $100,000 per violation. Any amounts received will be transferred to the Fund. Additionally, sponsors implementing non-compliant promotional programs may face similar legal actions. The Administrator can take civil action for unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo, with penalties of $100,000 per violation. Sponsors implementing non-compliant promotional programs may face legal actions. The Administrator must report actions taken under this section to Congress annually, including receipts, expenditures, and an evaluation of the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program. The Advisory Committee must provide an annual report on the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program, including receipts, expenditures, and program evaluation. Additionally, the Committee consults with NASA Centers for program improvement ideas. NASA has ten research centers including Ames, Dryden, Glenn, Goddard, JPL, Johnson, Kennedy, Langley, Marshall, and Stennis. The National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958 is amended to include the NASA Innovation Fund and Sponsorship Act of 2007. Definitions in the Act include terms like Administrator, NASA, Partnership Logo, and Promotional program.
